newsitem.title: HUNGARY: HUNGARY'S HORN SAYS FINMIN NOT MULLING RESIGNATION.
newsitem.headline: HUNGARY'S HORN SAYS FINMIN NOT MULLING RESIGNATION.

text.p: Hungarian Prime Minister Gyula Horn denied his Finance Minister Peter Medgyessy had raised the possibility of resignation over concessions to protesting farmers which would dilute his economic programme.
"(Medgyessy) did not hold out the prospect of resigning," Horn was quoted as saying by Hungarian television on Thursday.

Farmers from central Hungary's Kiskoros region have set up roadblocks since February 24 protesting that taxes were too high and demanding that they be exempt from making social security contributions.
On Wednesday they failed to show up to a meeting with Horn and Medgyessy after which Horn said negotiations were off.
"The government regards the talks as finished," Horn told reporters.
Medgyessy said he would remain in his post as long as no concessions are made to "preferred social sectors".
He added regular employees still pay twice as much tax as farmers do and that he would not agree to regulations that would result in unequal burdens.
"I am unwilling to agree to any substantial change affecting the proportionate sharing of tax burdens," Medgyessy said.
The statement comes only days after Medgyessy urged the government and social groups to agree to a programme of slashing inflation and curbing wage growth in 1998.
The comments apparently contradicted Horn who had earlier played down the importance of wage rises in generating inflation.
